newsitem.title: GERMANY: German cabinet approves second phase of tax reform.
newsitem.headline: German cabinet approves second phase of tax reform.

text.p: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's cabinet on Tuesday approved draft legislation which would carry out the lion's share of tax cuts planned by Finance Minister Theo Waigel, a government spokesman said.
Waigel's 1999 tax bill would sharply reduce income and corporate taxes in the second phase of a package which would cut the total German tax burden by around 30 billion marks.
The bill would slash the bottom rate of income tax to 15 percent from 26 percent, and set a new top rate of 39 percent, down from 53 percent.
It would also implement the second phase of corporate tax cuts which would lower the main rate to 35 percent from 47 percent now.

Legislation which would initiate cuts in corporate taxes in 1998 and cut the so-called solidarity surcharge, a levy to aid ex-communist east Germany, has already had its first reading in the Bundestag lower house of parliament.

Kohl will lead a government team into talks on Wednesday with the opposition Social Democrats (SPD) to try and find a compromise on tax reforms to avert deadlock in parliament, where the SPD can block tax measures in the upper house.
Kohl wrote in an open letter on Monday to SPD leader Oskar Lafontaine that the talks would be pointless if the SPD does not fundamentally agree to a cut in tax rates.

The SPD has supported cutting bottom rate income tax and corporate tax, but has opposed a big drop in top-rate income tax. It has also made its acceptance of the coalition tax reforms conditional on cuts in social insurance charges.
